Yes, here are some successful public health interventions that aimed to reduce rates of smoking and alcohol consumption and how they were implemented:

1. Higher Taxes on Tobacco Products: Various studies show that higher taxes on tobacco products do lead to a decrease in smoking rates. For example, in 2010, Turkey increased the taxes on cigarettes by 2.5 times, which led to a 13% reduction in smoking prevalence in just two years. This intervention was successful because it increased the price of tobacco products, which made them less accessible and affordable to the general public.

2. Quitline Services: Quitline services provide free access to counseling and support services to those who want to quit smoking. For example, in 2008, New York State launched its quitline service, which provided free counseling services, nicotine patches, and other quit aids to all New Yorkers. This intervention was successful because it provided an easily accessible resource for smokers who wanted to quit.

3. Restrictions on Advertising and Marketing of Alcohol: Studies show that restrictions on the advertising and marketing of alcohol can decrease alcohol consumption. For example, in 2003, France introduced a law that prohibited alcohol companies from advertising on television and in cinemas. This intervention was successful because it reduced exposure to alcohol advertising, which can influence people's drinking behavior.

4. Alcohol Taxation: Similar to tobacco taxation, higher taxes on alcohol products can lead to a decrease in alcohol consumption. For example, in 1983, the state of Alaska instituted a 10-cent-per-drink tax on alcohol. This intervention was successful because it increased the price of alcohol, which made it less accessible and affordable to the general public.

5. Designated Driver Campaigns: Designated driver campaigns encourage people to choose a sober driver if they are planning to drink alcohol. For example, in the 1980s, the United States launched its "Friends Don't Let Friends Drive Drunk" campaign, which encouraged people to choose a designated driver. This intervention was successful because it shifted social norms around drinking and driving, making it unacceptable to drive while under the influence of alcohol.
